div.l: And gadered him a meyne of his ougne sort
To hoppe and singe ⁊and make such disport
And there they setten steuen for to mete
And playen at the dys in such a strete
For in the toun nas there no Prentys
That fairer coude caste a peire of dys
Than Perkyn coude ⁊and therto he was fre
Of his dispence in place of priuete
That fonde his master wel in his chaffare
For ofte tyme he fonde his box full bare
For sikerly a Prentice reuelour
That haunteth dys ryott or paramour
His master shal it in his shoppe abye
All haue he no part of his mynstralcye
For thefte ⁊and riott they ben conuertible
All conne he pleye on giterne or ribible
Reuell and trouthe as in a lowe degre
They ben full wroth al day as men may se
This ioly prentice with his maister bod
Til he were ny out of his prentishod
All were he sn bbedsnibbedsn bbed bothe erli and late
And somtyme lad with reuell to Newgate
But ate laste his maister him be thouȝt
Vpon a day whan he his paper souȝt
Of a prouerbe that seith this same word
Well bet is roten̄ appill out of hoord
Than that it rote al the remenant
So fareth it be a riotous seruaunt
It is full lasse harme to late him passe
Than to shende al the seruauntes in the place
Therfor his maister yaf him aquetaunce
And bad him goo with sorwe ⁊and mischaunce
And thus this ioly Prentys had his leue
Now lat him riott al the niȝt or leue
And for ther is no thef withouten a lowke
That helpeth him to waste ⁊and to souke
Of that he bribe can or borwe may
A non̄ he set his bed and eke his array
Vnto a conpere of his ougne sort
That loued dys reuell and disport
And had a wif that helde for contenaunce
A shoppe · and swiued for her sustenaunce
A Prolog of the man̄ of Lawe
that the briȝt sonne / The Ark of his arti
ficall day hath ronne The fourth part
and half an houre ⁊and more And thouȝ he were
nat depe I sterte inlore He wist it was þᵉ xviij day
Of Aprille that is messanger of May
And saw wel that the shawe of eueri tre
Was as in lengthe the same quantite
That was the body erect that caused it
And therfor by the shadewe took his witt
That Phebus that shon fall clere ⁊and briȝt
Degrees was xliiij clombe on heighte
And for that day as in latitude
It was x of the clok he gan conclude
And sodeinly he pliȝt his hors aboute
Lordinges quod he I warne you al aboute
The iiij̉th part of this day is gon
Now for the loue of god ⁊and of seint Iohn
Lesith no tyme as ferforth as ye may
Lordinges the tyme wasteth niȝt ⁊and day
And steleth from vs priuily sleping
And what throw necligence in eure waking
As doth the streem that torneth neuer agan
Descending from the mountein into the plain
Wel can Senec and many a Philosophre
Be wailen tyme more than gold in cofre
For losse of catell may recouered be
But losse of tyme shendith vs quod he
Itwil nat come agein withouten drede
Nomore than Malkyns maidenhede
Whan she hath lost it in hir wantownnesse Lat vs nat mowlen thus
Sir man of Lawe quod he so haue ye blisse
Telle vs atale anon as forward is
Ye beth submitted be your for assent
To stande in this caas at my Iugement
Acquiteth you now of your behest
Than haue ye do your deuoir ate leste
Oost quod he depardieux ich assent
To brek forwardes is nat myn entent
Behest is dette and I wold holde it fayn
All my behest I can no better sain
For such lawe as a man yeueth an othir wiȝt
